alex.mojaki.boxes

Class WrapperBox<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • alex.mojaki.boxes.AbstractPowerBox<T>
      • alex.mojaki.boxes.DefaultPowerBox<T>
        • alex.mojaki.boxes.CommonBox<T>
          • alex.mojaki.boxes.WrapperBox<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - the type of the contained value, which subclasses should also implement.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Box<T>, PowerBox<T>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    CollectionBox, MapBox

    public abstract class WrapperBox<T>
extends CommonBox<T>
    A box which implements the same interface as the type of the value it contains and notifies its ChangeObservers when it is mutated via the change() method.

    This class does not enforce this description, but provides the machinery to do so easily, and you should subclass it with this intent. The source of MapBox is a good example of how this is done. Here are the steps to follow to create your own:

    1. Ensure that the type you want to wrap exists as an interface and that code typically uses that interface as a type instead of an implementing class. If implementations override equals, it should be possible for them to be equal to other implementations of the interface. If any methods of the interface return an object that is capable of mutating the callee, that return type should also be an interface.
    2. Create a class that extends WrapperBox<T> and implements T, where T is your interface.
    3. Implement the methods of your interface by forwarding method calls to the field value, e.g. @Override public int size() { return value.size(); }.
      • If the method might cause the value to change, call the change() method afterwards, e.g. void clear() { value.clear(); change(); }.
      • If the method must also return a value then the method change(Object) is convenient, e.g. V remove(Object key) { return change(value.remove(key)); }. In some cases changeIf(boolean) is also useful.
      • If the method returns an object that is capable of mutating the callee, the return type must be an interface and the return value must be an implementation that forwards and calls change() in a similar way. See the source of CollectionBox.iterator() and ListBox.subList(int, int) for examples.
    5. Override get() to just "return this;".

    This class should not allow users to access the underlying value or they could change it without notifying observers. This is why get() returns the object itself (by you overriding it as such). Because of this it doesn't make sense to add GetObserver or GetMiddleware, so these are disabled.

    Note that when you set a new value on a PowerBox, it will revert to the original value if an exception occurs in the middleware or observers, but no such rollback will occur here if there is an exception thrown by an observer after the value changes internally.

    See Also:
    ListBox, SetBox, MapBox

    • Method Detail

      • change

        protected void change()
        Notify all ChangeObservers. The parameters to ChangeObserver.onChange(PowerBox, Object, Object, Object) will all be this object. Call this method whenever the internal state of this value might have changed in such a way that is externally visible.

      • change

        protected <R> R change(R returnValue)
        Call change() and return the given value. This is just easier and shorter than manually saving the return value, calling change(), and returning the saved value.
        Parameters:
        returnValue - the value to return
        Returns:
        the parameter returnValue

      • changeIf

        protected boolean changeIf(boolean condition)
        Similar to change(Object), but only calls change() if the parameter is true. As well as being slightly nicer than a full if statement, this is especially convenient when the return value is an indication of whether there was a change, e.g. see CollectionBox.add(Object).
        Parameters:
        condition - the return value, and also whether the box's inner value has changed.
        Returns:
        the parameter condition.

      • rawGet

        protected T rawGet()
        Description copied from class: AbstractPowerBox
        Return the raw value this box represents, which may then be processed by middleware and observers. This can mean returning a field, the result of a calculation as in a View, the value of an inner box as in an AbstractUpgradedBox, or anything else.
        Overrides:
        rawGet in class DefaultPowerBox<T>

      • revealedToString

        public String revealedToString()
        Return the string representation of the underlying value (or "null" if the value is null), even if string values should be hidden for this box.
        See Also:
        BoxFamily.hideValueStrings(), AbstractPowerBox.toString()

      • equals

        public boolean equals(Object obj)
        Return whether the underlying value is equal to the argument, handling nulls appropriately. To avoid breaking symmetry in the equals contract, it is essential that implementations of the interface that this box contains allow equality between different implementations of the interface. For example, a LinkedList can be equal to an ArrayList because they check obj instanceof List, not e.g. obj instanceof LinkedList. Without this ListBox would not be possible.
        Overrides:
        equals in class Object

      • hashCode

        public int hashCode()
        Return the hash code of the underlying value, handling nulls appropriately.
        Overrides:
        hashCode in class Object

      • isNull

        public boolean isNull()
        Return whether the underlying value is null.
